title: Logistics company maps out Silk-y path to ASX
text:
Here's further proof Victorian-based transport and logistics company Silk Contract Logistics is preparing to fill the void left by Toll Holdings and Asciano's acquisitions.

Silk Contract Logistics, which offers wharf cartage, warehousing and distribution services across the country, has hired former 333 Capital dealmaker Paul Spottiswood as its new chief financial officer.

Silk Contract Logistics is expected to investigate a sharemarket listing in 2020 - and fill the hole left by Toll Holdings which was taken private in June 2015. Joe Armao

Spottiswood has advised the company on a handful of M &A deals, capital raisings and a management buyout in recent years and was hired to help with a potential ASX listing, according to a memo to staff from Silk Contract Logistics CEO Brendan Boyd and obtained by this column.

"Paul's extensive strategic, commercial, financial and legal experience will assist our business immeasurably as we embark on the next evolution of growth, including the possibility of an initial public offering on the ASX in coming years," Boyd told staff.

"In Paul's 20 years' experience, he has worked on acquisitions, investments, international expansion and capital raising activities in an extensive and diverse range of businesses (locally and internationally) including Transurban, Macquarie Group, P &O Maritime Services and most recently 333 Capital."
description: Here's further proof Silk Contract Logistics is preparing to fill the void left by Toll and Asciano's acquisitions.
